He called for an independent inquiry into the blaze.</p><p> The fire started more than a month ago after a lightning strike.</p><p> Mr Robertson said about a quarter of the wilderness area had been lost to fires since spring.</p><p> He said the department, as part of its burn-off strategy, firebombed a 6000ha block of the forest, causing spot fires that burnt out of control.</p><p> The department said it would welcome an inquiry and would brief conservation groups once mopping up was completed.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata nitf:lede="true">A METEOR exploded over New Zealand in daylight yesterday, prompting</p><p nitf:lede="true">hundreds of calls to emergency services around the nation.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Radio New Zealand said a forest fire near Napier on the east of the</p><p nitf:lede="true">North Island appears to have been started by falling debris.</p><p>The Carter Observatory in Wellington said the explosion and smoke at</p><p>around 1.45pm (Adelaide time) was heard and seen by people as far</p><p>apart as Rotorua in the north and Nelson at the top of the South</p><p>Island.</p><p>"It was picked up by aircraft and on radar, so we've had some air</p><p>traffic controllers calling, too," public programs officer Mr John</p><p>Field said.</p><p>Observers told of a bright flash, followed by an explosion and a cloud</p><p>of brown smoke hanging in the sky.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0N-JXK0-TXN5-S26M-00000-00Age of Miracles2004-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENT GUIDEPg. 8Age of MiraclesCD REVIEWSTerry Reilly

CD REVIEW: Age of Miracles, Chuck Prophet (New West/Shock) ****

He's not a household name, but Chuck Prophet, the former Green On Red guitarist, possesses an uncanny ability to quickly transform a blank canvas into his own off-centre design. He drives Age of Miracles at cruise control through a forest fire. Representative of this is Automatic Blues, which crackles so intensely, it could explode at any moment. This is the beauty of Prophet, a dedicated Bob Dylan, John Prine and Randy Newman buff. When not developing his own engrossing body of work - seven great albums so far - you'll find him shaping projects such as 2001's outstanding Raisins In the Sun with Jim Dickinson, Jules Shear and Harvey Brooks. Atmosphere is his forte, and West Memphis Moon, with its brutal storyline about three murdered children set against a howling, swamp-rock backdrop, is a haunting, radio-unfriendly classic. Collaborations with fellow individualists Kim Richey (Pin a Rose On Me) and Dan Penn (Heavy Duty) display a beguiling artistic integrity as both renowned songwriters contribute to a couple of impassioned hybrids, the latter originally intended for Solomon Burke. -- Terry Reilly

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YKD0-TXN5-R2WC-00000-00ANOTHER FIRE DISASTER LOOMS1987-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 23ANOTHER FIRE DISASTER LOOMSSource: Reuter

BEIJING, Friday: New forest fires triggered by lightning threatened to become China's second national disaster in two months, the Vice-Premier, Mr Tian Jiyun, said here today. Three separate blazes had burned more than 13,000 hectares of woodland in Inner Mongolia since lightning started them a week ago, the New China News Agency said.

Last month, 193 people died when a forest fire swept neighbouring Heilongjiang Province.

urn:contentItem:497B-8V10-015G-V3G8-00000-00<published>2003-08-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:09Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Protection falls short</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VOLUNTEER firefighter Ray Winter will not be riding his Licola Brigade's truck into a forest fire again.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "I just don't think I'd like to be in the cab, with all that plastic on the back," Mr Winter said.</p><p>"I wouldn't like to be on the back of that truck in a wildfire either.</p><p> "It's unsafe and I think too much of my life.</p><p> Licola captain Ralph Barra clough said that even the CFA's 1999 survival manual urged crews to shelter during fires in the fibreglass roll-over protection system on the truck's rear.</p><p> The manual says: "Tankers have a crew protection area in which personnel may take shelter from an approaching fire. These may consist of the vehicle's cabin and-or specially constructed heat shielding or roll-over protection compartment on the back."</p><p> Fellow Licola brigade member and beef producer Mark Coleman said the CFA had to phase out fibreglass.</p><p> "At least it's less likely aluminium or another metal is going to keep burning, like fibreglass, once the fire's passed," Mr Coleman said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0W-XC30-TXN5-T2S5-00000-00FIRE2002-01-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisPg. 14FIREbooks Elvira SprogisSteve Woodman

Sebastian Junger Fourth Estate, 224pp, $27.95

JOURNALIST and adventurer Junger, the author of The Perfect Storm, has produced a timely work of non-fiction that takes us to places few of us will, thankfully, ever experience.

'nl,8 Be they the inferno of a raging forest fire in the United States or the guerilla war in Afghanistan, the vicious diamond trade in Sierra Leone, the uncovering of the genocide in Kosovo or the uneasy peace in Cyprus.

Junger has the chilling ability to focus on the thoughts and feelings of the people caught up in these world-shaping dramas that we witness every night on the six o'clock news.

It brings home to our awareness that no matter what the scale of the tragedy, it is people like us, individuals, who are both victims and heroes.

His writing has a rare immediacy and one can almost hear the automatic gunfire, the roar of the flames and the cries of the injured.

A sobering read. Steve Woodman

urn:contentItem:4P8B-RF60-TXN5-V17B-00000-00Longer wait for fire case2001-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Longer wait for fire caseJODIE DUFFY

It has been 21/2 years since the Wingello bushfire tragedy, but three of the victims will have to wait another six months to have their cases heard before a jury.

On Friday the Supreme Court set down a special fixture in January, with the trial expected to run over seven weeks.

The crew's captain Michael Neale and Gail and Frank Pritchett are suing the State Government, Wingecarribee Shire Council and the Forestry Commission of NSW for compensation and damages.

Also being sued is forestry worker Graeme Charles McDonnell, who was attempting to lead a tanker back to the command post in a four-wheel-drive vehicle at the time a savage fireball swept through the area.

Volunteer firefighter David Quinlivan, 45, died in the forest fire.

The other four victims and some relatives have also begun legal action, but it will be some time before their cases are set down for trial or hearing.

BRIEFS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Stampede charges urged</p><p nitf:lede="true">ACCRA, Ghana -- A commission of inquiry has recommended charges against police over Africa's deadliest soccer disaster, a May 9 stampede in which 126 fans were killed.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It said yesterday it recommended prosecution for alleged reckless use of firearms by police, who fired teargas into crowds at Accra's main stadium.</p><p>Bandit Queen kill arrest</p><p>NEW DELHI -- The man accused of murdering "bandit queen" Phoolan Devi, was remanded in custody for 10 days yesterday.</p><p> Sher Singh Rana, arrested in the northern city of Dehradun, had earlier confessed to shooting her.</p><p> Fire threat to nuclear plants</p><p>MOSCOW -- A raging forest fire yesterday threatened a radioactive waste storage plant and forced the shutdown of a nuclear reactor.</p><p> Fire experts said the blaze began close to a Russian storage site for radioactive material in the southern Voronezh region, and quickly took hold.</p><p> MEANWHILE...nEASY TIME: Jeffrey Archer will start enjoying the easy life this week when he is switched to an open prison, after just a fortnight in a high-security jail.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P8H-NK10-TXN5-S0P0-00000-00Lloyd Cole - the Collection1999-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENT GUIDEPg. 8Lloyd Cole - the CollectionCD REVIEWSIan Beer

Lloyd Cole - the Collection, Lloyd Cole, (Mercury) ***½

Although Lloyd Cole never scaled the heights of his debut release with the Commotions back in 1984, there are enough recordings, both with his former band and overlooked treasures from his mostly tenuous solo career to make a worthy collection of greatest hits. Early chestnuts like Perfect Skin, Rattlesnakes and Forest Fire, on which Cole pours out his English romanticism with frail, emotive vocal chords, sit well among more earnest tunes in Don't Look Back and Downtown from his New York sojourn of the late

"80s. There was a time when Cole's music was touted as mere New Romantic fodder, but in the ever-forgiving retro-"90s when comebacks reign supreme, the 20 well-crafted tracks aired in this collection show him to be more than just a forgotten curiosity.

Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BUSHFIRES VIC 2 MELB (REOPENS)</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Later, central fire controller Richard Alder said NRE expected all edges of the alpine state forest fire would be contained by this evening.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But he warned that was no cause for complacency.</p><p>There had been 598 fires in Victoria so far this season - more than double the average of 266 fires faced by the state in that same November to January period for the past 20 years.</p><p> Mr Alder said this higher-than-average number of fires was coupled with extremely dry conditions.</p><p> "Over the past 12 months, rainfall in forests across the state has been close to the lowest on record, with many forests experiencing their lowest rainfall ever," he said.</p><p> Mr Alder warned campers not to leave fires unattended and to extinguish them with water, not soil or sand.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3RS0-MDM0-0048-T3T7-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="129"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:3VDM-7150-0048-T00V-00000-00<published>1998-12-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:05:09Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: Several fires burning across state</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SYDNEY, Dec 27 AAP - High temperatures and strong winds sparked a breakout of fires around New South Wales today, with several still burning.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The biggest blaze is at Cascade Creek, Wollondilly, south of Sydney, where 50 firefighters and 12 tankers are attending at 200 hectare forest fire.</p><p>Several grass fires are still burning in Muswellbrook, Tumut, Gundagai, Wingecarribe, Blacktown, Penrith, Leeton and Inverell.</p><p> A spokeswoman from the NSW Rural Fire Service said the fires were under control.</p><p>NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Phil Koperberg said conditions were ideal for fires.</p><p> "Whilst recent rain has tempered conditions somewhat, the hot weather over the last week reminds us how quickly circumstances can change," he said.</p><p> "In some areas Spring rain has caused grass to grow rapidly … many people would not have seen conditions like this for 15 years. The grass in some areas is two metres high."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="156"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGB0-TXN5-R321-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 9REGULAR SHORTS

CHINA FIRES FLARE AGAIN

PEKING, Wednesday: Several fires have flared up again in an area of north-east China devastated by the country's worst forest fire in memory, China's State television reported. It said the eastern sector of the fire zone was stable, with many people working to extinguish blazes still smouldering below the surface. "In the west, because of strong winds, several hidden fires flared above the surface. Forest police were air-lifted to fight them and an extra 1,000 soldiers were sent in to help." - Reuter

Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Blazes in Portugal a calamity</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LISBON: Portugal is to declare a national disaster over its worst forest fires in a generation, which have killed nine people in the past week, Prime Minister Jose Manuel Durao Barroso said yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"In the special Cabinet meeting, we plan to declare a public calamity, which will allow aid to be mobilised for people who have been particularly affected by this calamity," Mr Durao Barroso said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>"We are facing a tragedy such as Portugal has never faced in terms of (forest) fires."</p><p>Commander Antonio Santos, National Rescue Operations Centre officer, said more than 2300 firefighters were tackling 72 blazes, aided by more than 800 vehicles and five water-bombing planes.</p><p> Yesterday temperatures rose and winds fanned the flames sweeping through forests as dry as tinder after weeks of drought.</p><p>One blaze that took three days to extinguish last week burned down 11,000ha of woodland and was the biggest forest fire in 15 years.</p><p>About a third of Portugal is covered by forest and official figures show more than 26,000ha had been destroyed by fire in the year to July 27, before the recent wave of lethal fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Pg. 26</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Police ID for burning body</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON -- The burning body of a woman found in a forest near West Sussex was that of missing schoolteacher Jane Longhurst, police said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A Sussex police spokesman said yesterday that dental records were used to identify the body found in a nature reserve at 8.30pm yesterday as the missing music teacher.</p><p>A post mortem revealed Miss Longhurst, 31, who disappeared on March 14 from her Brighton home, was strangled and had been dead for some time.</p><p> The spokesman said her body had been set alight by an accelerant.</p><p> Police were alerted at 8pm after a motorist spotted a fire in trees and worried it may turn into a forest fire.</p><p> Firemen found the burning body at the densely treed area near a reserve, about 30m from a small road, which cuts across the common.</p><p> It was believed that her body had not been on the common for long.</p><p> Police have made extensive searches across Sussex in the hunt for Miss Longhurst.</p><p> Her mother Liz, sister Sue and long-term boyfriend, education welfare officer Malcolm Sentance, 34, have made TV appeals for help.</p><p> She was last seen by Mr Sentance when he left their home to go to work.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Injured fireman can stomach it</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Darrell Giles</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LOS ANGELES: Doctors will perform revolutionary surgery on a forest firefighter by tucking his burnt left hand inside his abdomen for three weeks in a bid to heal the skin.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Jason Emhoff survived the deadly Thirty Mile forest fire northeast of Seattle, Washington, earlier this month, but received burns to more than a quarter of his body.</p><p>Four young firefighters were killed and six others seriously injured in the massive blaze at Winthrop in the Cascade Mountains on July 10.</p><p>In surgery yesterday, doctors grafted Mr Emhoff's own skin on to his right hand.</p><p>Dr David Heimbach said the unusual procedure would be done on his left hand because blood vessels had been destroyed down to the tendons.</p><p>"We're going to make a little pocket in the abdomen and bury the left hand with skin on top of his fingers, so in three weeks' time the blood supply will grow into his hands," he said.</p><p>Then doctors could graft skin on top of the new blood vessels, he said.</p><p>The procedure, known as a Crane flap, has been done once before.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier ends</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ASHLEY GARDINER</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE marathon inquiry into the death of five firefighters at Linton more than two years ago finished yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Barristers for the parties involved have spent the past two weeks making their final submissions to State Coroner Graeme Johnstone, who will compile his report in the coming months.</p><p>Following final legal argument, Mr Johnstone closed the inquest without fanfare shortly before midday yesterday.</p><p> The five Country Fire Authority volunteers died on December 2, 1998, when their tanker was engulfed by a fireball fanned by a sudden wind change.</p><p> Matthew Armstrong, 17, Jason Thomas, 25, Chris Evans, 27, Stuart Davidson, 28, and Garry Vredeveldt, 47, were killed near Linton, south-west of Ballarat.</p><p> Over its 105 days, the inquest was told the Geelong West crew was "essentially an urban team" fighting a blaze in an unfamiliar environment.</p><p> Aside from the alleged lack of experience and training to fight a forest fire, it was also claimed the crew:</p><p> WERE using a wrong radio frequency.</p><p> DID not have enough water in their tank.</p><p> FAILED to keep already-burnt ground between them and the fire.</p><p> A finding is expected this year.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier As we know this is the transport that goes to the City and back to Manly via Dee Why and Warringah Mall and without this service one would have to walk up to the Skyline shops to do this.</p><p>I am therefore suggesting that residents do as suggested by the STA and ring up 131 500 or return the proposal to lodge your objection.</p><p>Keith Moss, Frenchs Forest</p><p>Fire brigades hold</p><p>bushfire details</p><p>SUPERINTENDENT Geddes is absolutely correct when he says "the Rural Fire Service cannot do it alone". It requires a major co-operative and co-ordinated commitment to minimise the impact of a large bushfire. Initially and essentially however, it is the standard of property maintenance and preparation that will dictate the firefighters' chances of saving houses and other structures. Your local brigade can provide you with this essential information.</p><p>Inspector Gordon Boat</p><p> Operational Commander</p><p> Forestville</p><p>More letters Pages 21,22</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier The area is famous for the Anzac and Allied campaign against the Turks in World War I. Governor Husnu Tuglu of Canakkale province said it was not immediately clear if any military cemeteries and war memorials were threatened.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>""History is burning here and we are powerless to stop it," he said last night. The fire has consumed 2000 hectares of pine forest. A senior fire official died of asphyxiation and five men in a watchtower inside the burning area were missing. The fire swept through the Eceabat national park, covering the Kocadere area where Turks fought Australian and New Zealand troops in 1915-1916.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGC0-TXN5-R2XB-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-05-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 12REGULAR SHORTS

CHINESE BUSHFIRE TOLL RISES TO 191

BEIJING, Monday: A forest fire which has killed 191 people and made 50,000 homeless during a 12-day sweep through north-east China is advancing on two towns, the China Daily reported today. The fire is only 15 kilometres from Mohe, China's most northerly town, and is again threatening Tahe, which was saved last week.

Forestry officials said strong winds and warmer weather had exacerbated the problem. Thirty-four thousand soldiers, firemen and civilians are fighting the blaze, hacking out firebreaks up to 50 kilometres long. - Reuter

A grass and forest fire was tonight<br/>burning out of control across 150 hectares near Flowerdale, north<br/>of Melbourne.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">But the Country Fire Authority (CFA) said it was not threatening<br/>any houses and was expected to be under control by daybreak.</p><p>A CFA spokesman said the fire had started about 5pm (AEDT) last<br/>night on private property but was now burning on mostly public<br/>land.<br/></p><p>The terrain was difficult to access and was "fairly hilly".<br/></p><p>The CFA and the Department of Natural Resources and Environment<br/>were battling the blaze with 23 tankers, 95 firefightrs and three<br/>bulldozers.<br/></p><p>Aerial waterbombing had also been used until dark fell last<br/>night, the spokesman said.<br/></p><p>"We're rather hopeful that by daylight we will have it<br/>contained."<br/></p><p>Meanwhile, another fire was burning across about 60 hectares of<br/>densely wooded country at Irrewillipe (Irrewillipe) near Colac in<br/>south-western Victoria.<br/></p><p>The CFA spokesman said while it had not been officially<br/>contained late last night, it also posed no threat to houses.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2001</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:42H2-5MG0-0048-T2CF-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-27</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="185"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2001 AAP Information Services Pty. nitf:lede="true">SMOKE from a huge forest fire in western Victoria blanketed Adelaide today as 400 firefighters battled to stop the blaze.</p><p>A south-easterly wind drove the smoke cloud about 450km from the fire in state forest 30km north-west of Portland.</p><p> There were no reports of private property damage, but at least 8000ha of timber and some open land was burnt.</p><p> Fierce overnight wind eased to 10kmh, helping firefighters who feared the fire could erupt again in high temperatures predicted for later this week.</p><p> A firebug was believed to have lit the fire in Tremaine Swamp wildlife reserve on Sunday night.</p><p> The blaze swept through Cobbobonee State Forest.</p><p> Residents recall nightmare, Page 26</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNP3-RV30-R558-00000-00No Headline1995-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisPg. 13No HeadlineCOSTELLO D

KEYWORD-HIT Romance LONDON: Supermodel Naomi Campbell is reportedly being romanced by a royal admirer _ playboy Prince Albert of Monaco. He invited her to the Red Cross Ball in Monte Carlo next month, the Daily Mail newspaper reported. Peace off KHARTOUM: Sudan's Islamic Government yesterday rejected a proposal from former United States president Jimmy Carter to extend a ceasefire with southern rebels. But as Carter ended a visit to Khartoum, a senior Sudanese official said the Government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army would resume peace talks soon to try to end the 12-year-old conflict. Fire out ATHENS: A huge forest fire which had raged through the outskirts of Athens for the last three days, gutting homes and destroying woodland, has been brought largely under control, the fire brigade said yesterday.

urn:contentItem:5560-2391-F0J6-J3N9-00000-00CHINA FIGHTS US BUSHFIRE1988-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:05:09ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 50CHINA FIGHTS US BUSHFIRESource:Reuter

China is donating 200 fire extinguishers and sending experts to help fight a two-month-old blaze which has destroyed half of the Yellowstone National Park in the US.

A US Embassy spokeswoman in Beijing said the donation was thought to be the first time China had given aid to the US.

The People's Dailysaid the high-quality pneumatic extinguishers were effective in fighting a huge forest fire in northeast China in 1987 which killed nearly 200 people.

A Chinese team would train Yellowstone firefighters in their use, and more fire experts would be sent if needed, the report said.

The forest fire disaster in Indonesia has reduced timber resources and this will keep up the pulp prices in Indonesia and neighboring areas.</p><p> (XIC)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SY1-W8R0-0048-T2CR-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="166"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. The Daily added weather conditions _ snowfalls and light winds _ should help firefighting efforts. Firefighters were being parachuted in to cut firebreaks and soldiers and civilians were clearing away debris. Associated Press</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNN3-RTWS-G17W-00000-00'HISTORY' BURNS AT GALLIPOLI1994-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:27ZLexisNexisPg. 3'HISTORY' BURNS AT GALLIPOLI

KEYWORD-HIT "History' burns at Gallipoli ANKARA: A fire chief died and five people were missing in a forest fire which has raged since yesterday through Turkey's Gelibolu (Gallipoli) peninsula. The area is famous for the Anzac and Allied campaign against the Turks in World War I. Governor Husnu Tuglu of Canakkale province said it was not immediately clear if any military cemeteries and war memorials were threatened. ""History is burning here and we are powerless to stop it,'' he said last night. The fire has consumed 2000 hectares of pine forest. A senior fire official died of asphyxiation and five men in a watchtower inside the burning area were missing. The fire swept through the Eceabat national park, covering the Kocadere area where Turks fought Australian and New Zealand troops in 1915-1916.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bushfire threatens northern homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SUE BAILEY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A BIG forest fire threatened homes, closed a highway and destroyed eight square kilometres of bushland in northern Tasmania yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> About 30 firefighters from 11 fire units were last night keeping a close watch on the fire south of Lefroy on the East Tamar.</p><p>At the height of the blaze a pall of smoke hung over Launceston's northern suburbs.</p><p> Paul Hodges, group officer with the Dalrymple group of brigades, said quick action by firefighters stopped the fire destroying any homes or farm property.</p><p> "There were no evacuations but a couple of houses were threatened though it was not a big problem," Mr Hodges said.</p><p> "There were a couple of times we thought we'd lost it but the proficiency of the volunteer firefighters won out.</p><p> "We used two bulldozers to set up fire breaks and that way we were able to save adjoining farmlands so it was mainly bush that was destroyed."</p><p> The Flinders Highway between Bell Bay and Bridport was closed for about four hours because of the blaze.</p><p> It is not known how the fire started.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:44DX-S6R0-015G-T558-00000-00<published>2001-06-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 39</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>$16m for chopper crash</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SANTA ANA, California -- A jury has ordered the world's largest helicopter manufacturer to pay $16.6 million to the widow of a veteran pilot who died while fighting a forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The jury found Bell Helicopter Textron responsible for the death of 51-year-old Floyd Hiser, who died in 1997 when fuel stopped flowing to his engine and his helicopter crashed into the San Bernardino Mountains.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>"Bell Helicopter knew it had a problem and didn't do anything about it," juror Bryan Curtis said.</p><p> Bell lawyers contended that Mr Hiser did not put enough fuel in the tank.</p><p> Sharon Hiser was grateful jurors did</p><p>not buy the notion her husband flew recklessly.</p><p> "Floyd didn't do anything wrong. He was trapped. He had no place to go," Mrs Hiser said.</p><p> The 206L-1 model produced by Bell was widely used by law enforcement agencies, fire departments and television news crews.</p><p> About 1700 choppers produced in the 1980s came under scrutiny by pilots who complained the aircraft lost power in flight.</p><p> Federal regulators did not find any problems with the helicopter's fuel system design but sent a letter warning pilots to properly service the system.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FED: URGENT TRAINING NEEDED FOR FIREFIGHTERS IN INDONESIA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CANBERRA, Oct 24 AAP - Australian experts today called for urgent training for firefighters battling to contain forest and bush fires on the Indonesian islnd of Sumatra.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Out of Australia's $2 million assistance for the Indonesian forest fire crisis training and equipment for the teams should be the top priority, the federal government's overseas aid agency AusAID said.</p><p>"In southern Sumatra, where local ground firefighting operations were observed, the team reported an urgent need for training and basic equipment provision," AusAID said in a statement.</p><p> Two Australian aerial water-bombing planes have continued to fly sorties attacking fires in Lampung Province in southern Sumatra.</p><p> The planes have flown 332 successful sorties and dumped 972 tonnes of fire suppressant on the fires, the statement said.</p><p> At least six Indonesians have died of haze-related ailments and 40,000 others estimated to have been affected.</p><p> Timber and plantation companies have been blamed for starting the fires to clear their land.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4C90-0048-T200-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="173"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:44DX-H870-015H-93K3-00000-00<published>2001-02-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Flare sparks</p><p nitf:lede="true">police alert</p><p nitf:lede="true">POLICE and marine emergency services were placed on alert last night after the reported sighting of a distress flare near Granville Harbour on Tasmania's West Coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Police said the report was received about 9pm.</p><p>Fire rings</p><p>alarm bells</p><p>A FOREST fire on Eaglehawk Neck last night sparked a barrage of calls from as far away as Mt Nelson.</p><p> The blaze was visible from Hobart and created more panic in distant population centres than among locals. A Tasmania Fire Service spokesman said the blaze looked spectacular but was safe enough for most crews to leave the fire scene by 11pm.</p><p>Top jazz band</p><p>at the Gorge</p><p>INTERNATIONAL jazz band Natural Gas will make a special guest appearance at this year's A Night in the Gorge concert in Launceston on February 24.</p><p> It will support the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra and the Three Chinese Tenors.</p><p>Remanded on</p><p>theft charges</p><p>A MAN was remanded in custody after he appeared in court charged with the theft of $20,000 from a safe.</p><p> Nathan Charles Mills, 21, of no fixed address, appeared in the Burnie Magistrates Court yesterday charged with burglary and stealing.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata nitf:lede="true">Firefighters were today trying to control a forest fire near the Mt Buller ski resort.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But a Conservation, Forests and Lands fire-control officer said the fire had been halted and 50 firefighters were working hard to control it.</p><p>He said police had been asked to investigate the fire which burnt through about 40ha of inaccessible snow gum country yesterday and overnight.</p><p> The officer said it was likely the fire had been intentionally lit.</p><p> During the height of the blaze, there were fears for the Mt Buller resort 4km away, but heavy aerial bombing with chemicals slowed its progress.</p><p> The flames were finally checked as the night cooled.</p><p> Department firefighters also would watch nine other fires around the state after outbreaks yesterday.All were minor and under control, the officer said.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Torrid day of dust and flames</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A HAZE which hung over the metropolitan area yesterday was caused by strong north-westerly winds carrying dust from dry paddocks in the north.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The problem was more severe on parts of Eyre Peninsula.</p><p>Southern Yorke Peninsula was buffeted by winds of up to 50km/h which hampered Country Fire Service efforts to battle a fire which began at 12.30pm.</p><p> The blaze destroyed 200ha of scrub about 5km south of Warooka before it was contained by 60 firefighters late yesterday.</p><p> A 200sq m forest fire in the South-East was contained by Forestry SA firefighters and a CFS firebombing aircraft which dropped foam on the fire.</p><p> It began in a block of 1958 pines near Glencoe nursery at 4pm.</p><p> The CFS, Forestry SA and police were investigating the cause.</p><p> And two bomber aircraft helped CFS crews contain a grass fire near Mylor just before 4pm.</p><p> The cause of the blaze, which was contained to 250sq m, is not known.</p><p> Fire also blackened about 2ha of grassland behind O'Sullivan Beach Football Club late yesterday.</p><p> It was extinguished at 5.50pm by Metropolitan Fire Service crews.</p><p> The temperature in Adelaide peaked at 38.2 degrees at 2.24pm yesterday  making it the hottest March 17 on record.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Since the beginning of the dry season five months ago, more than 12,000 ha of forest have been destroyed by forest fires.</p><p> (VNA)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SH3-H0J0-0048-T1J4-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="188"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGC0-TXN5-R1V3-00000-00CHINA FACES THREAT FROM SOVIET FIRE1987-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:26ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1CHINA FACES THREAT FROM SOVIET FIRESource: Associated Press

BEIJING, Sunday: Chinese firefighters, exhausted from an 18-day battle with the nation's worst forest fire in decades, face a new threat from a major fire approaching from the Soviet Union, the official news agency Xinhua said today.

The news agency report from Hohhot, capital of China's Inner Mongolia, said north-westerly winds had pushed the Soviet fire another two kilometres toward the Chinese border, and it was now only eight kilometres from the border.

It said the fire has been slowed somewhat by low temperatures and light showers, but is likely to cross the 150-metre wide Ergun River dividing the two countries if the winds pick up.

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-49V0-0048-T3T4-00000-00<published>1997-10-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FED: AUSTRALIA PROVIDES $300,000 AID TO IRIAN JAYA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CANBERRA, Oct 28 AAP - Australia is to donate $300,000 for emergency food aid for villagers in remote parts of Irian Jaya.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer said the money would go to World Vision Australia for distribution in areas affected by the drought which is also ravaging Papua New Guinea.</p><p>He said World Vision had been active in Irian Jaya for more than 20 years and was well placed to implement emergency relief operations.</p><p> "Over 400 deaths have been reported in the Jayawijaya district since the onset of food and water shortages caused by the extended drought and frost damage to local crops," he said in a statement.</p><p> "It is estimated that two thirds of children in the targeted villages are severely malnourished. Alongside these children, women, sick and old people will be given priority assistance."</p><p> Mr Downer said the grant to World Vision followed a recommendation from the Australian health assistance team sent to Indonesia by AusAID earlier this month.</p><p> He said the $300,000 formed part of the $2 million aid provided for forest fire and drought relief in Indonesia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-49V0-0048-T3T4-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="187"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. Australia today promised $1 million in drought aid for the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said 400,000 people faced starvation in Irian Jaya, which borders Papua New Guinea where 500,000 people are also at risk because of severe drought.</p><p>"A UN disaster assessment team which recently visited the worst affected areas found Irian Jaya is on the verge of famine," Mr Downer said in a statement.</p><p> "Smoke from forest fires is severely restricting flights carrying food into the affected regions.</p><p> "The UNDAC team also reported that local water supplies are drying out and the little water left is polluted resulting in more people suffering diarrhoea, scabies and respiratory tract infections."</p><p> Mr Downer said half of Australia's donation would go to a United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA) appeal and the other half to the International Committee of the Red Cross.</p><p> Australia has already donated $7 million towards drought relief in Papua New Guinea, while $3 million has now been committed to Indonesia for drought and forest fire assistance.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-41T0-0048-T44X-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="191"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7M-CWG0-TXN5-R2FN-00000-00BRIEFS1990-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:26ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 8BRIEFS

HUGE BLAST AT SOVIET ARMY BASE

PRAGUE, Wednesday: A powerful explosion ripped through a Soviet military area in south-east Czechoslovakia yesterday and Prague's Defence Ministry said Soviet troops had blown up an ammunition dump in violation of regulations.

"The explosion was a result of a breach of all possible regulations," a Defence Ministry spokesman said after the blast was reported by Czechoslovak radio today.

"A powerful explosion in the Soviet military area of Libava in south-east Czechoslovakia occurred last night, sending a mushroom-shaped orange cloud into the sky and sparking a forest fire," the station said.

Firefighters were rushed to the site but could not gain access, it said.

Analysis of ash samples showed that they were not radioactive and did not contain harmful chemicals, the station said.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Radioactive dust released WORLD</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KIEV: A forest fire near the Chernobyl nuclear plant has released an unknown amount of deadly radioactive dust into the atmosphere, officials admit.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Vadim Grishenko, of the Ukrainian Environment Ministry, said radioactive particles disturbed by the fire would "threaten the outside population".</p><p>The blaze, which started around noon on Tuesday, swept through five abandoned villages and surrounding countryside within 10km of the contaminated site.</p><p> It was fanned by strong winds and took seven hours to bring under control.</p><p> The cause of the fire was thought to be a cigarette discarded by picnickers visiting graves near their former homes.</p><p> The explosion at Chernobyl, which happened 10 years ago this week, scattered fallout over a large part of Europe.</p><p> The extent of radioactivity from the blaze, about 10km northwest of the power plant, was not immediately clear and reports were conflicting.</p><p> But an official said it threatened to spread well beyond the 30km exclusion zone surrounding the plant.</p><p> A Greenpeace spokesman said: "This is clearly a danger to the health of people, and not only in Ukraine." </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Record heat brings dust and fires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A HAZE which hung over the metropolitan area yesterday was caused by strong north-westerly winds carrying dust from dry paddocks in the north.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The problem was more severe on parts of Eyre Peninsula.</p><p>Southern Yorke Peninsula was buffeted by winds of up to 50km/h which hampered Country Fire Service efforts to battle a fire which began at 12.30pm.</p><p> The blaze destroyed 200ha of scrub, about 5km south of Warooka, before it was brought under control by 60 firefighters late yesterday.</p><p> A 200sq m forest fire in the South-East was contained by Forestry SA firefighters and a CFS firebombing aircraft which dropped foam on the fire.</p><p> It began in a block of 1958 pines near Glencoe nursery at 4pm.</p><p> The CFS, Forestry SA and police were investigating the cause.</p><p> And two bomber aircraft helped CFS crews contain a grass fire near Mylor just before 4pm.</p><p> The cause of the blaze, which was contained to 250sq m, is not known.</p><p> Fire also blackened about 2ha of grassland behind O'Sullivan Beach Football Club late yesterday.</p><p> It was extinguished at 5.50pm by Metropolitan Fire Service crews.</p><p> The temperature in Adelaide peaked at 38.2 degrees at 2.24pm yesterday  making it the hottest March 17 on record.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Qingdao, a port city in east China's Shandong Province, vows to move all local residents who live in shelters into apartment buildings by the end of the century.</p><p>The city started related work in 1993 and by the end of 1997, 18,000 families have moved into new houses.</p><p> XINHUA DAILY TELEGRAPH</p><p> 1. A serious forest fire which broke out in north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region on May 13 had still not been brought under control by yesterday.</p><p> CHINA DAILY</p><p> 1. China and Canada have signed contracts to expand bilateral telecom ties. At a signing ceremony yesterday in Beijing, China's Stone Group clinched a deal to buy US$600,000 worth of TV equipment from ABL Canada Inc., Hunan Water Conservancy Information Center reached a 2.5 million US dollar contract with Harris Communications to build a flood control communication alarm network in the Dongting Lake area, and Gansu Posts and Telecommunications Bureau planned to spend US$4 million to purchase a point-to-point microwave system from SR Telecom Inc.</p><p> (XIC)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SR8-NVT0-0048-T3BJ-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="199"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. In the past two weeks, the fire has killed more than 200 people and made 50,000 homeless in Heilongjiang province. The Government said men and material were pouring into the area, including 300 men with 18 pieces of artillery and 10,000 shells which can be fired at clouds to try to create artificial rain. The Chinese Air Force is flying in relief donated by the JapaneseRed Cross. Floods are sweeping Guangdong province of south China leaving 63 dead and 33,000 homes destroyed. Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BUSHFIRE RAGES IN ISRAEL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JERUSALEM - Fire whipped by desert winds raged through 1000 hectares of forest on the edge of Jerusalem today, forcing the evacuation of five villages.Twenty-two people were taken to hospital, two in serious condition, after inhaling smoke.</p><p>Smoke drifted over the holy city where a smell of burning filled the air from what state radio described as the worst forest fire for years.Temperatures soared to 37 degrees, a 111-year high for July 2 on the Jaffa coast where Tel Aviv stands.Police closed the main highway to Tel Aviv, causing huge traffic jams, as a thick pall billowed from the mainly pine woods on the Judaean hills.A major communications centre and a television station at Neve Ilan, 10km from Jerusalem, were shut and several houses caught fire.In the village of Shoresh, hotel guests gathered around a swimming pool for safety before being rescued.Firemen appealed for volunteers to help bring the blaze under control.- AFPEND OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>EXODUS: ORTHODOX JEWS WALK TO SAFETY AFTER BEING EVACUATED FROM NEVE IIAN WHERE SEVERAL HOUSES CAUGHT FIRE.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Twelve firemen and three civilians died in the fire, the worst such tragedy in a country plagued every summer by forest fires. Four of the firemen died when the vehicle they were sheltering under to escape the flames blew up. About 20 villages in the hilly, timber-producing region were evacuated and many farmers lost property and livestock. (Reuter)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
